{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3410970,"name":"Wihy","username":"Wihy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wihy/{size}/225659_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-24T21:53:51.729Z","cooked":"

I was wondering if anyone ever had to use something more advanced than a profile with FF and PID for control. Cases where PID + FF just didn’t cut it.

From my not very vast experience most problems(practically all I had to solve) could be solved quickly with high precision with only these 3 things, assuming well tuned constants.

If PID + FF are not always enough, what are the edge cases you encountered? Where did PID + FF fail?
If they are always enough, what are the benefits of more advanced control? I suppose I’m asking more specifically about things such as state space control and current-control. (I’m aware that these are very different things)

I’m sure people here with much more experience than me will have useful insight on this. Thanks in advance!

not exactly controls, but Choreo uses more advanced motion planning for drivebase motion given the tighter power constraints on it than other mechanisms.

While I still feel fairly early on in my controls journey even after 5 years of mentoring at this point.

I can strongly reccomend checking out Controls Engineering in the FIRST Robotics Competition from @calcmogul as it likely has some form of answer for you.

Also i feel this is topical.

Especially the part concerning how “seriously most problems can be solved with PID”

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-07-24T23:42:32.184Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":25,"reads":329,"readers_count":328,"score":310.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":469101,"topic_slug":"advanced-control-in-frc","display_username":"Eric (319)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://file.tavsys.net/control/controls-engineering-in-frc.pdf","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":45}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23786,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Awaiting our Robot Overlords since 2013"},"post_url":"/t/advanced-control-in-frc/469101/3","custom_user_title":"Awaiting our Robot Overlords since 2013","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"call_me_hand","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3411021,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-25T00:24:50.076Z","cooked":"
Wihy:

If PID + FF are not always enough, what are the edge cases you encountered?

Systems with coupled dynamics or more than 2 states. At that point, you just generalize to an array of P controllers; spamming LQR on a linear approximation of the system is unreasonably effective.

For example, LQR applied to a differential drive, which has coupled dynamics between the two sides, gets you a controller of the form \mathbf{u}_k = \mathbf{K}(\mathbf{r}_k - \mathbf{x}_k) where \mathbf{u}_k is a vector of control inputs (left and right motor voltage), \mathbf{K} is a 4x4 matrix of proportional gains, \mathbf{x}_k is a vector of states (left and right wheel velocity), and \mathbf{r}_k is a vector of references (PID calls these setpoints).

\mathbf{u}_k = \begin{bmatrix} \text{left motor voltage} \\ \text{right motor voltage} \end{bmatrix} \\ \mathbf{K} = \begin{bmatrix} k_1 & k_2 \\ k_3 & k_4 \end{bmatrix} \\ \mathbf{x}_k = \begin{bmatrix} \text{left wheel velocity} \\ \text{right wheel velocity} \end{bmatrix} \\ \mathbf{r}_k = \begin{bmatrix} \text{left wheel velocity reference} \\ \text{right wheel velocity reference} \end{bmatrix}

Multiplying this matrix equation out gives the following two control laws:

\begin{align*} u_{left} = &k_1 (r_{left} - x_{left}) + k_2(r_{right} - x_{right}) \\ u_{right} = &k_3 (r_{left} - x_{left}) + k_4(r_{right} - x_{right}) \end{align*}

k_2 and k_3 help compensate for how movement on one side of the drivetrain affects the other.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-07-25T00:24:50.076Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":296,"readers_count":295,"score":114.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":469101,"topic_slug":"advanced-control-in-frc","display_username":"Tyler Veness","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend"},"post_url":"/t/advanced-control-in-frc/469101/4","custom_user_title":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3411027,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-25T00:55:58.309Z","cooked":"

While not FRC, in college robotics, I wanted to achieve the fastest possible response time so the robot could track rapid user inputs, which resulted in the use of cascade control with real-time motion profiling generated directly from a model of the system dynamics. This creates a motion profile which almost but not quite constantly saturates the output allowing for near optimal response times without stability issues.

Using a model to generate motion profiles by directly solving for maximum possible accelleration allows you to account for some non-linearity such as dry friction, input saturation, and simple arms and apply the appropriate forwardness as well as eliminate all feedforward tuning and shorten feedback tuning because you can use analytic methods to derive the appropriate gains and quickly tune the feedback gains using simulation.

Wihy:

current-control. (I’m aware that these are very different things)

Current control specifically is generally easier to model and avoids inductance-related issues that can occur from voltage controlled motors. The problem with voltage control is that voltage across a motor is not directly related to either speed or acceleration and is instead, is a related to a combination of both in addition to inductance effects which can cause some annoying edge-case behavior. Current control utilizes the much faster controllers on board the motor controller to force the desired current, which is directly proportional to torque via the torque constant of the motor.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-07-25T00:55:58.309Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":239,"readers_count":238,"score":72.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":469101,"topic_slug":"advanced-control-in-frc","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/advanced-control-in-frc/469101/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3411366,"name":"sam liu","username":"catrix","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/dbc845/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-26T08:27:31.909Z","cooked":"

At least for my team, SysId + Trapezoid PID + proper FeedForward is good enough to control any specific mechanisms like an arm, elevator, or shooter. Because for most teams, the robot is 50% CNC + 50% Handmade, everything is not that accurate in the first place. And the game itself never demands teams to do millimeter-level controls.
But for things like pose estimator or trajectory planning, something more advanced is needed. But for most students like you and me, we just have to learn the APIs, not a lot of dudes spend time reading the code inside.
I guess the chapter “Advanced Controls” in WPILIB docs is more of an introduction to these esoteric concepts so that it will be easier for us to learn about them in detail when we go to college. I mean, it’s always no harm to learn something new.
